title: Trilogy - Bonding, structure, and the properties of matter
subject: Science

85F563E0020845C79C2AE3C757AECCAC.description: Give examples of the uses of fullerenes, including carbon nanotubes.

FEE73E048B274D36858E7B454B972089.description: Recognise graphene and fullerenes from diagrams and descriptions of their bonding and structure

AF6739C405684A8E9BA151C8669F51E9.description: Recall that their properties make them useful for nanotechnology, electronics and materials.

B6CE74508E494C16B0D6CB3F5836E890.description: Recall that carbon nanotubes are cylindrical fullerenes with very high length to diameter ratios.

967C1C7BF3C74C6DB392442B17974EF1.description: Recall that the first fullerene to be discovered was Buckminsterfullerene (C60) which has a spherical shape.

7BFF449F3EA041D4876204DF3E1A0BD8.description: Recall that its properties make it useful in electronics and composites.

5B68F740F92F428BB24784F41182E86B.description: Recall number of bonds per carbon in graphite

7502F99519E64DEC984917DC342E84B1.description: Explain why diamond has a high melting point

D72215326254420BAC38BA28D4A0B7CA.description: Recall that diamond doesn’t conduct electricity.

8A0EB91D137C4BBE9E2DF4C405E626B4.description: Recall that diamond is very hard and has a very high melting point.

B894C86AE22B4DE098048E73700AC359.description: Explain these properties of metals in terms of their structure and bonding.

C92061A2AE16469785C6842DCF509188.description: Explain why metals conduct thermal energy

5667EF78F43D4FCAB0FB5F9C43D627CE.description: Recall that metals are good conductors of thermal energy.

FF1DD171843D440B8208B677B3448C14.description: Recall that metals are good conductors of electricity.

49E6183C3E314C6D9BFCD2BFB89513BD.description: Explain the properties of alloys (when compared to pure metals)

490D24584CA64285BABB90CBA3594668.description: State what an alloy is and describe how the atoms are arranged.

47FBAAAF33AF4D9EA6B3D2FFF6FF83F4.description: Describe the arrangements of atoms in pure metals.

3D1D918B3AB94FFDB1CA85B9B1184797.description: Recall that these strong metallic bonds mean that most metals have high melting and boiling points.

84E2962C4930451EB51EF3005094B893.description: Recall that metals have giant structures of atoms with strong metallic bonds.

A3A0A822FCC2485ABF1A711A4B2E52DB.description: Recognise giant covalent structures from diagrams showing their bonding and structure.

377EF6AF4CF34733BC661A1AC4841F0B.description: Recall that diamond and graphite (which are forms of carbon) and silicon dioxide (silica) are examples of giant covalent structures.

0915C822615C433DA3BE4F0FCB9CACCD.description: Describe what happens when these substances melt or boil, with reference to the covalent bonds present.

4FBD28C1A0174016B293F56D80A57E2A.description: Explain the properties of giant covalent structures in terms of their structure and bonding.

6A04117E55FB4E258A63D0FFB39A2F59.description: Recall that all of the atoms in these structures are linked to other atoms by strong covalent bonds.

6014D3101FD44798AEC068801208F2A8.description: Recall that substances that consist of giant covalent structures are solids with very high melting points.

0FAFE64D9BAD4EA38C73A65446BDBA6F.description: Define the elements present in hydrocarbons

5E5CE0D157DA43AF836486650CABE152.description: Recognise polymers from diagrams showing their structure and bonding.

A905E5ECC54E43EAAA224ECA2BF79AFE.description: State the relative strength of the intermolecular forces between polymer molecules, and the effect this has on their state at room temperature.

D5EE1CAB9C754F9CB1C5CCEA722085CA.description: Recall that polymers have very large molecules, and that the atoms in the polymer molecules are linked to other atoms by strong covalent bonds

EA05B849650F400E8DCAED6ADB33B09F.description: Use ideas about the strength of intermolecular forces and covalent bonds to explain the bulk properties of molecular substances.

D38243FFA7384F68975E807027D414AE.description: Explain the properties of small molecules in terms of their structure and bonding.

0892165180DC40718CA092726FBE9521.description: Recall that these substances don’t conduct electricity.

B9B57F2432A447FAB56DFA721323FE25.description: Describe how these forces change as the size of the molecules increase, and the effect this has on the melting and boiling points of substances.

D8814AE8ABC64D59A7000C3CE6B112FC.description: Describe what happens when these substances melt or boil, with reference to the intermolecular forces present.

51DD42643BF6494581710CEB15D94F3E.description: Recall that substances which consist of small molecules are usually gases or liquids and have relatively low melting points and boiling points.

907419761EC24ED4AF62DACF7311DDEC.description: Explain which states of ionic compounds conduct electricity
